# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here's a function that matches your description:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Int=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(dt::Date, bump::Int)
    throw(ArgumentError("timezone_bumper only works with DateTime types, not Date"))
end
```

Example usage:

```julia
# Working with DateTime
dt = DateTime(2023, 4, 1, 12)  # April 1st, 2023, 12:00
timezone_bumper(dt)             # This will bump the time to 15:00 of the same day
timezone_bumper(dt, 1)          # This will bump the time to 13:00 of the same day

# Not working with Date
d = Date(2023, 4, 1)            # April 1st, 2023
# timezone_bumper(d)            # This will throw an error
```

Note that this function will not automatically adjust for daylight saving time or time zone differences. It'll strictly add the specified number of hours to the input `DateTime`.
